intro: Oxytropis bryophila, commonly known as the smallleaf locoweed, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its small, trifoliate leaves and yellow flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats such as sagebrush steppe and grasslands. It has a deep taproot system that allows it to survive in arid conditions. Oxytropis bryophila is also known for its toxic properties, containing alkaloids that can be harmful to livestock.
